Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Identify number names and representations of number
Elaboration: Participating in activities, stories, songs and music that involve number names, numerals and quantities; for example, nodding as objects are counted, tapping an object as it is counted, assisting to move objects from one container to another as each object is counted, or repeating some number names as objects are counted

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Identify number names and representations of number
Elaboration: Participating in activities that model one-to-one correspondence, such as putting pegs on a string number line one by one, when counting is being modelled

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Identify number names and representations of number
Elaboration: Responding to number names in everyday situations; for example, waiting for counting down or counting up before starting an action (‘Three, two, one, go’) or stepping, clapping, vocalising, making a sound or tapping a switch for each number being counted

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Identify number names and representations of number
Elaboration: Observing and indicating representations of numbers in a familiar environment; for example, identifying numerals in the classroom, even if they are not always correct in naming the numerals, such as saying ‘two’ when the numeral is 5

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Identify, name and represent ‘one’ and ‘more’ using physical and virtual materials
Elaboration: Representing ‘one’ using a single object; for example, handing over one object when asked for ‘one’, pointing to the one object when shown a group of objects and one object, or looking at the single object when asked ‘Where is one?’ when offered 2 options

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Identify, name and represent ‘one’ and ‘more’ using physical and virtual materials
Elaboration: Identifying collections as either ‘one’ object or ‘more’ objects; for example, saying ‘more’ or a bigger number to indicate collections that are more than one, or indicating the group of objects when shown collections of ‘one cow’ and ‘more cows’

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Identify, name and represent ‘one’ and ‘more’ using physical and virtual materials
Elaboration: Using an action, gesture or vocalisation to indicate when they want more or fewer objects

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Compare the quantity of collections using direct comparison to identify which has more or if they are different
Elaboration: Participating in collections being directly compared; for example, matching quantities of 2 groups to identify which one has ‘more’

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Compare the quantity of collections using direct comparison to identify which has more or if they are different
Elaboration: Participating in the comparison of groups using modelled counting; for example, observing modelled counting using one-to-one correspondence and identifying whether 2 groups of objects are ‘different’ or which group has ‘more’

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Compare the quantity of collections using direct comparison to identify which has more or if they are different
Elaboration: Comparing collections of familiar objects by directly matching quantities of each group to determine if they are different; for example, lining up 2 collections and using matching to determine if the collections have a different number

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Compare the quantity of collections using direct comparison to identify which has more or if they are different
Elaboration: Using direct comparison to respond to questions about group composition; for example, observing students lined up in 2 rows and responding to questions such as ‘Are they different?’ and ‘Which one has more?’

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Partition and combine collections to make ‘more’ or ‘different’
Elaboration: Partitioning a collection of objects into 2 groups and using matching and direct comparison to determine if the number of objects in each group is ‘different’; for example, partitioning a group of 5 pencils by placing one pencil in a container and 4 pencils in another container and identifying which group has more

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Partition and combine collections to make ‘more’ or ‘different’
Elaboration: Joining 2 collections of objects together; for example, connecting 2 towers of blocks together to make one tower

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Partition and combine collections to make ‘more’ or ‘different’
Elaboration: Splitting an object into 2 parts and determining if they have different sizes; for example, breaking playdough into 2 unequal sections and comparing their sizes to determine which section has ‘more’

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Partition and combine collections to make ‘more’ or ‘different’
Elaboration: Joining 2 parts together to make a whole; for example, squashing 2 balls of playdough together to make one big ball or pushing together 2 horseshoe magnets to make one circle

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Add or take away objects, using physical and virtual materials and matching to determine whether the changed total is more or different
Elaboration: Starting with 2 collections with the same quantity, then adding or taking away objects from one collection to make the collections different; for example, matching elements in 2 equal collections of strawberries and taking one away from, or adding one to, one of the collections, and matching to determine if the totals are different or which collection has more

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Add or take away objects, using physical and virtual materials and matching to determine whether the changed total is more or different
Elaboration: Responding to questions about group composition after 1 of 2 collections with the same starting quantity has changed, such as responding to ‘Which has more?’ and ’Are they different?’

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Add or take away objects, using physical and virtual materials and matching to determine whether the changed total is more or different
Elaboration: Participating in modelled counting with demonstrated one-to-one correspondence; for example, assisting in counting the starting number of a collection of objects, and adding one or taking away one object from the collection and re-counting to find the changed total

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Add or take away objects, using physical and virtual materials and matching to determine whether the changed total is more or different
Elaboration: Role-playing situations that involve simple money transactions using a group of one-dollar coins to ‘pay’ for physical items

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Share physical objects and collections equally in practical situations
Elaboration: Sharing objects equally among a group; for example, giving each group member a biscuit from a packet of biscuits or a book from the library shelf

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Share physical objects and collections equally in practical situations
Elaboration: Distributing objects to others in everyday situations by demonstrating one-to-one correspondence; for example, handing out one paintbrush to each student from a collection of paintbrushes

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Share physical objects and collections equally in practical situations
Elaboration: Participating in sharing a collection of objects; for example, giving each student a sticker until all the stickers are gone

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Share physical objects and collections equally in practical situations
Elaboration: Responding to yes/no questions about the equal and unequal sharing of objects or collections using direct comparison, such as ‘Does anyone have a different amount?’ and ‘Who has more?’

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Initiate and repeat actions that have an effect
Elaboration: Creating patterns through songs and music; for example, moving a shaker to start a pattern

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Initiate and repeat actions that have an effect
Elaboration: Repeating actions or sounds in familiar songs, stories or games, such as ‘A sailor went to sea’, We’re going on a bear hunt and pat-a-cake

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Initiate and repeat actions that have an effect
Elaboration: Identifying the first element of a repeating pattern comprising at least 2 elements; for example, touching a shape on a device to continue a pattern

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Initiate and repeat actions that have an effect
Elaboration: Using repeated actions in play or to generate an effect; for example, sorting shape blocks in a shape sorter, placing puzzle pieces into a puzzle tray, stacking blocks, moving a bell or an egg shaker to generate a noise or tapping a drum

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Identify whether 2 familiar objects are ‘big’ or ‘little’, using direct comparison
Elaboration: Sorting everyday familiar objects by size, using direct comparison; for example, sorting square and circle shapes of the same colour into 2 collections based on size

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Identify whether 2 familiar objects are ‘big’ or ‘little’, using direct comparison
Elaboration: Using direct comparison to compare the lengths of 2 objects; for example, lining up a stapler and a ruler next to each other and responding to the question ‘Which one is big?’ or ‘Which one is little?’

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Identify whether 2 familiar objects are ‘big’ or ‘little’, using direct comparison
Elaboration: Experiencing the modelled language of measurement when comparing objects in a pair that are big and little

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Identify whether 2 familiar objects are ‘big’ or ‘little’, using direct comparison
Elaboration: Responding to yes/no questions about measurement attributes when directly comparing the sizes of objects, such as responding to the questions ‘Is this circle the little circle?’ and ‘Is this circle the big circle?’ when the teacher shows 2 different-sized circles

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Recognise and participate in routine and non-routine daily events
Elaboration: Responding to familiar signals for transitions; for example, lining up when the school bell rings indicating the end of lunch or packing up an activity on the signal from a timer

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Recognise and participate in routine and non-routine daily events
Elaboration: Responding to regular routines and their representation on a visual schedule; for example, using a ‘first-then’ card to transition from one familiar activity to the next or placing items in a finished box

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Recognise and participate in routine and non-routine daily events
Elaboration: Responding to a change in daily schedule through the co-creation of a visual schedule, such as a ‘first-then’ card or an individual visual schedule, and then transitioning to the changed activity

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Match and sort objects and shapes that are ‘big’ or ‘little’, using direct comparison
Elaboration: Matching shapes to the correct spaces in inset puzzles

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Match and sort objects and shapes that are ‘big’ or ‘little’, using direct comparison
Elaboration: Comparing physical and digital representations of two-dimensional shapes to identify attributes that are ‘big’ or ‘little’; for example, ‘posting’ items into different containers or holes to sort different-sized familiar shapes, using object cutters to reproduce a shape with playdough or using other malleable materials to make shapes that have different sizes

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Match and sort objects and shapes that are ‘big’ or ‘little’, using direct comparison
Elaboration: Sorting a large collection of objects into ‘big’ or ‘little’ groups; for example, sorting a collection of cars and animals into a ‘big’ group and a ‘little’ group based on size

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Indicate the location of known objects within a familiar environment
Elaboration: Responding to the language of location and direction through modelled daily routines; for example, looking upwards for ‘up’, using rhymes and chants that relate to movement, following a warm-up sequence for sport, unpacking their bag, washing their hands or getting their lunchbox before lunch

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Indicate the location of known objects within a familiar environment
Elaboration: Participating in games and activities to reinforce the concept of object permanence; for example, answering yes/no questions when playing a game in which a familiar object is moved while they are not looking, or searching for a preferred object that has been hidden and indicating its location when found by gesturing, pointing or vocalising

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Indicate the location of known objects within a familiar environment
Elaboration: Participating in activities that develop the concepts of ‘in’ and ‘out’; for example, putting objects ‘in’ and ‘out’ of a container when asked, or following routines and instructions that involve moving between inside and outside locations

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Indicate the location of known objects within a familiar environment
Elaboration: Responding to yes/no questions about location of self, people or objects, such as ‘Is teddy on the floor?’, ‘Is Tuan next to Amy?’ and ‘Is the teddy in the same place as before?’

Subject: Mathematics
ContentDescription_V2: Indicate the location of known objects within a familiar environment
Elaboration: Responding to one-step directional language and communication used in the daily routine, such as ‘sit down’, ‘stand up’ and ‘look here’ during an activity or program
